goal.en: IMPORTANT: This course was specifically designed for our English third-year students. If you have taken Prof. Laura Pérez‘s Writing Through Media, Expository Writing or if you are NOT an English junior, you will not be able to enroll given the objectives of my course. This theory and practice-based course seeks to provide students with critical thinking abilities to convey content in written form based on exercising exposition, argumentation and dialogue. To do so, we will pay attention to the theme of education and public scholarship through the philosophical concept of praxis.

content.en:
ALL COURSE CONTENT WILL BE PROVIDED IN
ENGLISH.
All weekly sessions comprise (i) a lecturing part;
and (ii) an exercise section.
This three-part course is motivated by the following
questions:
Introduction: What does ‘praxis‘ mean?
Section 1. What are the aims of education?
Section 2. What is public scholarship?

textbook.en: A copy of the course material will be ready on February 22. References include text, visual and audio material. Some required and optional references could be modified in order to comply with course discussions. Key course references: Chesterman, Andrew ＆ Emma Wagner. (2002). Can Theory Help Translators? A Dialogue Between the Ivory Tower and the Wordface, Manchester: St. Jerome Publishing. Culbertson, Kristin. (2020). “Teaching Philosophy to Non-Majors as a Form of Public Philosophy.” Public Philosophy Journal: 3(2). Fleerackers, Alice ＆ Carina Albrecht. (2019). “You-niversity? Perceptions on the Public Effectiveness of University Knowledge Production.” Public Philosophy Journal: 2(1). Baehr, Jason. (2020). “Intellectual Virtues, Critical Thinking, and the Aims of Education” In Miranda Fricker, Peter J. Graham, David Henderson and Nikolaj J.L.L. Pedersen, The Routledge Handbook of Social Epistemology, Routledge, pp. 447-456. Kotzee, Ben. (2019). “Education and Epistemic Injustice.“ In Kidd, Ian James, José Medina, Gaile Pohlhaus Jr. (eds.), The Routledge Handbook of Epistemic Injustice, Routledge, pp. 324-335. Lani Watson. (2020). “Educating for Good Questioning as a Democratic Skill,” In Fricker, Miranda, Peter J. Graham, David Henderson ＆ Nikolaj J.L.L. Pedersen (eds.) The Routledge Handbook of Social Epistemology. Routledge, 2020, pp. 437-446. Levinson, Meira. On The Aims of Education (2015). In Philosophy Bites. Wainwright, Joel (2022) Praxis, Rethinking Marxism, 34:1, 41-62, DOI: 10.1080/08935696.2022.2026749 Weitz, Morris, 1956, “The Role of Theory in Aesthetics,” Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism 15: 27-35.
